docs.lead_paragraph: Lisa Brown does not consider herself a violent person. She still has lunch twice a week with the 91-year-old widower of a woman she served as a home health aide and treats her four cats as though they were children. But when Osama bin Laden interrupted her peach Danish this morning, Ms. Brown said she longed to smash through her TV screen and strangle him.

headline.main: Many TV Viewers Criticize Smirks and Invocations of Allah
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE NATIONAL REACTION

docs.abstract: Americans in Illinois react with anger and hatred to videotape showing Osama bin Laden bragging and laughing about Sept 11 terrorist attack; Arab-Americans say they are appalled at bin Laden's invocation of Allah and Koran; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doubts about mammography are not new. Though many women and their doctors think of annual mammograms after age 40 as normal and necessary, there have long been vocal skeptics. Their dissident view about the usefulness of mammograms may seem to have been fully validated by the study published this fall in The Lancet, concluding that women who have mammography die of breast cancer at the same rate as those who don't. But the issue of breast cancer screening isn't so easily settled. For most of the 20th century, physicians thought that breast cancer was a local disease that only spread to the rest of the body late in its course. Early detection, they assumed, meant that the cancer would be caught and treated before it could kill. So it made perfect sense that the American Cancer Society began in the 1950's to encourage women to perform breast self-examinations and in the 1970's to recommend mammograms.

headline.main: Breast Cancer Is a Complicated Enemy

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Barron H Lerner, professor of medicine, says doubts about mammography are not new, but issue of breast cancer screening is not easily settled; says his current strategy for women under 50--those for whom doubts about mammography's value are strongest--is to encourage individual choice; says for women 50 to 70, he will continue to recommend yearly mammography because there has been so much supportive data for so long; says he will be less willing to insist on mammograms for patients who decline them; says doctors must be willing to challenge most basic assumptions about how to fight breast cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the troubled health insurance giant, said yesterday that it would eliminate 6,000 jobs, or about one-sixth of its work force, and take a $125 million charge in the fourth quarter as it struggled to regain profitability. The job cuts -- including 360 in Hartford, Middletown and Windsor, Conn.; 444 in New Jersey; and 659 in Pennsylvania -- reflect Aetna's dwindling enrollment. It has lost 1.8 million health plan members this year, now at 17.5 million from 19.3 million in January, and it expects to lose more members as it raises rates and eliminates unprofitable Medicare and commercial health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: Aetna Will Cut 6,000 Jobs, About a Sixth of the Work Force

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc, struggling health insurance giant, will eliminate about 6,000 jobs, or one-sixth of its work force, as it struggles to regain profitability; has lost 1.8 million health plan members in 2001 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Steve Collins is a skilled tire builder. For 17 of his 22 years at the Firestone plant here, he worked nights. His wife has not worked for 13 years, since the second of three children was born. On his wages, now $23 an hour or about $46,000 a year, he said, ''I built the house, got the toys -- the boat, the cars.'' But when the factory closes for good on Friday, Mr. Collins will be among 1,500 Firestone workers who will be out of jobs. When the last tire leaves the two-million-square-foot plant, Mr. Collins, 45, will be just three months short of the 23 years he needs for a full and immediate pension and lifetime health insurance.

headline.main: An Illinois Tire Plant Closes and a Way of Life Fades

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans in Congress pressed ahead today with negotiations on an economic recovery package, seeking to overcome substantive differences even as they positioned themselves to avoid blame if their efforts failed. The negotiators said they intended to try to narrow their differences over the next few days in the hope of coming up with a compromise that could be voted on before Congress finishes its work for the year next week.

headline.main: Congress Takes Small Steps on Economic Aid

docs.lead_paragraph: Hewlett Heir Intensifies Opposition to Compaq Deal Walter Hewlett, the most outspoken opponent of Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq Computer, stepped up the pressure with a letter urging the boards of both companies to abandon the proposed merger. In his letter, Mr. Hewlett, a Hewlett-Packard board member, said that in recent meetings with large shareholders he found ''enormous unhappiness'' about the deal. [Page C4.] Aetna to Eliminate 6,000 Jobs Aetna, the troubled health insurance giant, said that it would eliminate 6,000 jobs, or about one-sixth of its work force. [C7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Parity for Mental Health'' (editorial, Dec. 10): We applaud your dispelling the myths with facts: parity will not increase health care costs more than 1 percent. If cost is not the deterrent, why, then, has this discrepancy in our health care coverage lasted so long? The answer lies in stigma. Throughout our nation's history, we have viewed mental illness with ignorance, fear and misunderstanding. We have thought of and acted differently toward people with mental illness than we have toward people with physical illness.

headline.main: To Douse the Fire in the Mind

docs.abstract: Letter from Gail Kamer Lieberfarb says stigma of mental illness is reason why discrepancy in health care coverage has lasted so long (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiations about an economic recovery package hinged today on President Bush's insistence that any plan include a cut in personal income tax rates, a provision that Congressional Democratic leaders said would be hard for their members to accept. Both parties said all issues were on the table as the administration and Congressional leaders made one last push to reach a deal on an economic stimulus bill before the House and Senate go home for Christmas.

headline.main: Prospects for Stimulus Plan Hinge on Bush Demand for Tax Cuts

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Both Mike Wallace and Dr. David Fassler assert (Op-Ed and letter, Dec. 11) that severe mental illness should have parity with severe physical illness regarding insurance coverage. It's difficult to see how any informed and reasonable person could disagree with that. What probably most frightens third-party payers is the risk of costly claims for the treatment of ''problems of living'' that are not severe mental illness, but can be represented and perceived (by patients, by others) as if they were.

headline.main: To Douse the Fire in the Mind

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Everett Dulit says health insurance providers are frightened about risk of costly claims for treatment of 'problems of living' that are not severe mental illness, but can be represented and perceived as if they were; calls for development of sensible criteria (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The current lack of parity for mental health (editorial, Dec. 10) is no surprise. Most people, including legislators, still regard mental illness in children and adults as a character defect attributable to a moral failing of the individual and his or her parents. Community support for an individual with a physical life-threatening illness abounds. The individual with a life-threatening mental illness is often overlooked.

headline.main: To Douse the Fire in the Mind

docs.abstract: Letter from Joann Lindenmayer says there is lack of parity for mental health because most people, including legislators, regard mental illness as character defect (S)
